notes.ptext: Gaseous hydrogen is colourless.
Hydrogen burns with little or no flame.
Gaseous helium is colourless.
Helium glows bright white when a high voltage is applied to it.
A helium dischage tube.
This specimen of lithium is coated with a dark layer of oxides and nitrides.
Lithium is found in trace amounts in the mineral lepidolite.
Small pieces of beryllium.
A 5g bead of 98.5%+ pure beryllium. About 2cm in diameter.
Crystalline boron. 0.2 g.
10 grams of crystalline boron in small pieces.
One of carbon's many allotropes. 0.2g
Carbon's best known allotrope, diamond. These are rough diamonds from Venezuela. 0.1 g.
A large piece of graphite, that easily marks paper (as well as your hands!).
Gaseous nitrogen is colourless. Amount; 3 ml.
A small amount of liquid nitrogen.
Gaseous oxygen is colourless. Amount; 3 ml.
A small amount of liquid oxygen showing its characteristic light blue colour.

Elementary fluorine corrodes glass, therefore in place of it is a very old fluor-spar (calcium fluoride) containing traces of radioactive material is shown here. Elementary fluorine is set free by the decay, which is released when breaking the mineral and is recognizable by its characteristic smell. Amount; 0.4 g fluor-spar, fluorine unknown.
This is real elementary Fluorine, enclosed in quartz glass, which resists corrosion better than ordinary glass. Amount; 2.5 ml.
Some fluorite fragments, typical of the different pastel shades of fluorite.
Gaseous neon is colourless. Amount; 3 ml.
Applying high voltage to gaseous Neon makes it glow bright orange-red
A neon dischage tube.
Beautiful luster without oxidized spots. Amount; 0.2 g.
Sodium burns with a beautiful yellow flame.
Small pieces of magnesium ribbon. Amount; 0.1 g.
A solid piece of magnesium, 3g, over 2.5cm long. Greater than 99.8% pure.
Some crystals of dolomite from the Tri-State mining district near Joplin, Missouri USA. Dolomite is an commercially important source of magnesium.
These rhombohedral crystals of magnesite measure about 50mm from left to right.
0.2 of aluminium foil.
A piece of kitchen foil at 60x magnification.
The most important aluminium ore. It was named after the village "Les Baux-de-Provence" in southern France, where it was first discovered in 1821 by geologist Pierre Berthier.
High-purity silicon for the manufacture of silicon chips. Amount; 0.3 g.
10 grammes of solid silicon. Greater than 99% pure.
A small amount of poisonous white phosphorus stored under water to avoid autoignition.
A pile of (harmless) red phosphorus.
Crystalline sulfur. Amount; 0.2 g.

Sulfur is a component of many of the complex organic compounds that are found in crude oil. It also occurs as hydrogen sulfide in natural gas. This piece of sulfur came from a natural gas plant near Tioga, North Dakota (USA).
Chlorine's green-yellow colour can just be seen here.
Gaseous argon is colorless. Amount; 3 ml.
Applying high voltage to gaseous argon causes it to glow.
An argon dischage tube.
Beautiful luster without oxidized spots. Amount; 0.6 g.
Some potassium compounds, showing their varying colours in water.
A sylvite crystal (potassium chloride in natural mineral form).
Some small lumps of calcium. Amount; 0.9 g.
A 10 gramme ingot about 2.5cm square. 99% pure.
A mineral source of calcium, this variety of fibrous gypsum is called satin spar. This specimen is from Verde Valley, Arizona USA.
Small pieces of very rare scandium. Amount; 0.1 g.
A piece of pure scandium in dendritic form. 10 grammes in weight and 99.5% pure.
Small pieces of titanium. Amount; 0.3 g.
A large piece of rutile, a mineral source of titanium.
A lump of vanadium. Amount; 0.6 g.
A small cube of pure vanadium. Weighs around 10g.
Vanadinite is one of the main industrial ores of the metal vanadium and a minor source of lead. This piece is from south west Africa, about 90mm across.
Chromium in crystalline form. Amount; 0.2 g.
A very shiny ingot of chromium. Weighs 10g, 99%+ pure.
Chromite is the most important mineral source of chrome.
Some small pieces of manganese. Amount; 0.8 g.
Psilomelane is one of the most abundant manganese ores.
Pyrolusite is one of the most abundant manganese ores.
Pure iron without carbon. Amount; 1.1 g.
Hematite is an important iron mineral. The specimen is from the Montreal Mine in Hurley, Michigan USA.
Magnetite is an important iron mineral. These octahedral magnetite crystals are from Cerro Huanaquino Potosi, Bolivia.
A small, 1.0g, lump of cobalt.
Pieces of nickel sheet. Amount; 0.3 g.
A small piece of thick copper wire. Amount; 1.7 g.
A mineral source of copper. This azurite rose of intergrown crystals comes from Utah, USA.
Some small pieces of zinc. Amount; 0.8 g.
A 50g cast ingot of 99.9% pure zinc. 36mm in diameter and 8mm thick.
A large piece of zincite, a good source of zinc.
A small rod of gallium. Gallium will melt in your hand.
Gallium melts just over room temperature. Amount; 0.6 g.
Small pieces of germanium. Amount; 0.3 g.
A shiny piece of germanium chopped from a larger piece. 10g, 2.5cm long and 99.999% pure.
A small piece of grey arsenic. Amount; 0.4 g.
Many pieces of selenium shot. Amount; 0.7 g.
Solid selenium ingot weighing around 80g and 7.5cm in diameter. 99.95% pure.
Vapours of the pure bromine fill the entire vial. Amount; 0.2 g.
Gaseous Krypton is colourless. 3ml.
Applying high voltage to gaseous krypton causes it to glow light blue. 3ml.
A krypton dischage tube.
A rubidium vapour lamp manufactured by Osram.
A 2.5cm square ingot of 98%+ pure strontium. Approx. 20g.
A little bit tarnished (oxidised). Amount; 0.2 g.
A group of strontianite (white) crystals, an important strontium mineral.
A 2.5cm square chunk of yttrium cut from a larger piece. 50g in weight, 99% pure.
Pieces of yttrium. Amount; 0.4 g.
Small pieces of zirconium. Amount; 0.5 g.
A small zircon crystal. The oldest minerals found so far are zircons from Western Australia, with an age of 4.404 billion years.
Solid niobium slug weighing 3.5g. 99.95% pure.
Small pieces of niobium. Amount; 0.7 g.
Pyrochlore is good mineral source of niobium.
99.95% pure molybdenum slug weighing 4 g.
Small molybdenum ribbons. Amount; 0.2 g.
Some rounded molybdenite crystals, a good source of molybdenum.

Technetium is quite radioactive. Pitchblende (an Uranium ore) is shown here, where spontaneous fission of U-238 creates tiny amounts of Technetium. Amount; 0.2 g Pitchblende, corresponding to 0.1 pg or 600 million atoms of Tc.
A chequered piece of ruthenium. Amount; 0.3 g.
A 99.9% pure pellet of solid ruthenium weighing 10g. 14mm in diameter.
A 1g pellet of 99.9% pure rhodium, 6mm in diameter.
Rhodium is one of the most expensive precious metals. Amount; 0.4 g.
Small strip of palladium. Amount; 0.3 g.
An ingot of pure palladium, 36mm in diameter, 8mm thick.
Many beads of silver. Amount; 1.1 g.
99.1% pure silver ingot. Produced around 1863, from the Chico Ledge Mine, Nevada.
A sterling silver chain at 200x magnification.
A lump of cadmium. Amount; 0.9 g.
A pancake shaped ingot of 99.9%+ pure cadmium. 50g, 36mm in diameter and 8mm thick.
Small piece of indium. 1.3 g.
Solid indium cast ingot. 28g in weight and 31mm in diameter. 99%+ pure.
Beads of tin. Amount; 1.2 g.
A rod of solid tin weighing 1 kilogram.
A group of lustrous cassiterite (tin oxide) crystals.
Cast ingot of 99%+ pure antimony weighing around 40g. 36mm in diameter and 8mm thick.
Small pieces of antimony. Amount; 0.8 g.
A group of stibnite crystals, a source of antimony.
A beautiful cast piece of pure tellurium showing dazzling crystalline surfaces. 99.9% pure, 30g, 38mm in diameter and 6mm thick.
Small pieces of tellurium. Amount; 0.7 g.
Iodine in crystal form at room temperature. 0.7g.
When heated iodine sublimates (turns from a solid to a gas) into a violet vapour.
Gaseous xenon is colourless. 3ml.
Applying high voltage to xenon causes it to glow dark purple.
A xenon dischage tube.
Gold-yellow cesium doubly encased in an inner vial. Amount; 50 mg.
Pollucite is one of the main cesium minerals.
An oxidised barium ingot. 98% pure, 20g, 25mm in diameter.
A little bit tarnished. Amount; 0.5 g.
A solid ingot of 99% pure lanthanum. 75g and 36mm long.
The film of lanthanum oxide on the surface makes the metal blue. Amount; 0.4 g
99% pure cerium ingot of about 25g and 20mm in length.
The film of cerium oxide on the surface makes the metal blue. Amount; 0.4 g
An ingot of 99% praseodymium. Weighs 50g, about 25mm long.
A lump of Praseodymium. Amount; 0.5 g.
A 75g ingot of 99% pure neodymium. About 3cm long.
A small piece of Neodymium. Amount; 0.3 g.

image.title: Promethium used on a watch hand

notes.ptext: The luminous paint on the hand contains traces of radioactive promethium.

image.title: Promethium used on a watch hand (glowing)

notes.ptext: Using a long exposure time the glowing can be photographed in the dark.
A small piece of samarium. Amount; 0.5 g.
A piece of samarium that has been chopped off a larger piece. 5g in weight, 99.5% pure.
This piece of europium shows a multitude of colours due to a thin film of oxidation on the surface. 25g, 99.9% pure, about 2.5cm wide.
A small piece of Europium. Amount; 0.6 g.
A small ingot of 99% pure gadolinium. Weighs 75g.
Gadolinium is the only ferro-magnetic rare earth metal. Amount; 0.4 g.
A 99.5% pure ingot of pure terbium. 25g in weight.
A lump of Terbium. Amount; 0.5 g.
A 75g ingot of 99% pure dysprosium.
A piece of Dysprosium. Amount; 0.2 g.
A 75g chunk of holmium. 99% pure.
Holmium powder. Amount; 0.1 g.
A 35g ingot of 99.9% pure erbium.
A few swarfs of Erbium. Amount; 0.3 g.
A 25g chunk of 99% pure thulium, one of the rarest of rare-earth metals.
Thulium powder. Amount; 0.4 g.
A 25g of 99.9% pure ytterbium. Notice that the yellow colour is natural.
A few swarfs of Ytterbium. Amount; 0.2 g.
5g chunk of 99.5% pure lutetium. Considered the rarest of the Lanthanide series.
Lutetium powder. Amount; 0.2 g.
A few swarfs of Hafnium. Amount; 0.5 g.
100g of 99.95% pure tantalum in a 38mm square block.
Pieces of Tantalum. Amount; 1.2 g.
Small lumps of tungsten. Amount; 0.9 g.
A good source of tungsten.
A piece of rhenium sheet. Amount; 0.2 g.
A one gram pellet, 6mm in diameter. The element with the second highest melting point of all elements. 99%+ pure.
A 5g pellet of 99.9% pure osmium, the heaviest metal. 8mm in diameter.
Compressed osmium powder. Amount; 0.4 g.
Small piece of iridium. Amount; 0.9 g.
Large rod of iridium. Making a rod of this size is very difficult due to iridium's high melting point, extreme hardness and britleness. 22 Troy ounces.
A small strip of Platinum. Amount; 0.1 g
A rod of solid platinum weighing 21 troy ounces. At July 2006 prices this rod is worth around US$25,500.
A small piece of gold sheet. Amount; 0.5 g.
A solid gold ingot from the Tolkuma Gold Mine, New Guinea.
18ct white and yellow gold ring at 150x magnification.
Gold in a vein of quartz.
A small amount of toxic mercury. Amount; 5.0 g.
Some hexagonal cinnabar crystals (red). Cinnabar is the most important mercury mineral.
A 10g disk of 99.9% pure thallium. 13mm in diameter and 6mm thick.
Beads of Thallium. Amount; 1.8 g.
A large piece of lead. Amount; 2.2 g.
A 60g cast ingot of 99.9%+ pure lead, 36mm in diameter and 8mm thick.
The mineral galena (grey) is the main lead mineral.
Bismuth is the last of the stable elements. Amount; 1.2 g.
A nicely shaped cast ingot of bismuth. 2.5cm wide, approx. 80 grammes. 99%+ pure.
A piece of naturally occuring metallic bismuth.
A bismuth crystal that has been grown in a bismuth smelter. They tarnished to produced the iridescence on the surface.

Po-210 (half life 138 days) is part of the decay chain of U-238, so traces of Polonium exist in the pitchblende shown here. Amount; 0.7 g pitchblende, corresponding to 25 pg or 70 billion atoms of Po-210.

At-218 (half life 1.6 seconds) is part of the decay chain of U-238, so traces of Astatine exist in the pitchblende shown here. Amount; 0.2 g pitchblende, corresponding to 0.002 ag or 6 atoms of At-218.

Rn-220 (half life 56 seconds) is part of the decay chain of Th-232, so traces of Radon are released by the thorium oxide shown here. Amount; 0.9 g Thorium oxide, corresponding to 6 ag or 16000 atoms of Rn-220.

Fr-223 (half life 22 minutes) is part of the decay chain of U-235, so traces of Francium exist in the pitchblende shown here. Amount; 0.1 g pitchblende, corresponding to 0.36 ag or 950 atoms(!) of Fr-223.
This luminous paint contains traces of a radium salt. Amount; 50 mg, Radium fraction unknown.
With a long exposure time the glowing can be photographed (in the dark).

Ac-227 (half life 21.8 years) is part of the decay chain of U-235, so traces of Actinium exist in the pitchblende shown here. Amount; 0.1 g pitchblende, corresponding to 12 pg or 30 billion atoms of Ac-227.
A small amount, 0.9g, of tungsten impregnated with thorium, 20mg.

Pa-231 (half life 32700 years) is part of the decay chain of U-235, so traces of Protactinium exist in the pitchblende shown here. Amount; 0.2 g pitchblende, corresponding to 37 ng or 100 trillion atoms of Pa-231.
Metallic uranium (U-238) as powder, about 0.1g.

Np-237 (half life 2.14 million years) is produced by nuclear reactions in U-238, so traces of Neptunium exist in the pitchblende shown here. Amount; 0.4 g pitchblende, corresponding to 47 fg or 120 million atoms of Np-237.
A small pellet of plutonium glowing under its own light.

This is trinitite, a mineral from the area of the first atomic bomb test in New Mexico. The sand was melted by the heat and encloses traces of Plutonium. Amount; trinitite 0.2 g, Plutonium fraction unknown, but very small.

This is trinitite, a mineral from the area of the first atomic bomb test in New Mexico. The sand was melted by the heat and encloses traces of Americium, created from Plutonium by neutron capture. Amount; trinitite 0.2 g, Americium fraction unknown, but very small.

This is trinitite, a mineral from the area of the first atomic bomb test in New Mexico. The sand was melted by the heat and encloses traces of Curium, created from Plutonium by neutron capture. Amount; trinitite 0.2 g, Curium fraction unknown, but very small.
